title: Welcome to the Lab
text:
This project analyzes biomechanics data from the OpenBiomechanics Project, an open-source initiative by Driveline Baseball.
The data is captured in their motion capture lab using high-speed cameras and computer vision to track an athlete‚Äôs body. This allows for sub-millimeter accuracy in tracking joint centers and skeletal movement.


Below is a video directly from the Driveline lab showing how the capture system works:

title: Welcome to the Lab
text:
About This Site
I built this site to correlate body kinematics (how they move) with pitch metrics (how the ball flies).
Navigate to the analysis tabs to see: * Hip-Shoulder Separation: Does stretching the core lead to more velocity? * Arm Stress: Which mechanics put the most torque on the elbow?

title: About The Project
text:
Reason i built this site
make sure they work!
Link to the GitHub Repository to THIS website
Wasserberger KW, Brady AC, Besky DM, Jones BR, Boddy KJ. The OpenBiomechanics Project: The open source initiative for anonymized, elite-level athletic motion capture data. (2022).

title: The Stride Fallacy probably get rid of this
section: ‚ÄúThe LONGER you stride the HARDER you throw‚Äù
text:
‚ÄúThe LONGER you stride the HARDER you throw‚Äù

The Hypothesis
Conventional baseball wisdom suggests that: The farther you stride the harder you will throw. Is that true?

title: The Stride Fallacy probably get rid of this
text:
The Data
We analyzed stride length (normalized as a percentage of body height) versus fastball velocity for our pitcher cohort.










üîª Click Here for the Legend


Axis's:
 Stride length is the linear distance from the pitching rubber to the center of the lead foot at foot contact.


Key Insight:
 Manzi et al. (2022) found that increased stride length is associated with higher ball velocity.


Citation: Manzi, J. E., et al. (2022). Journal of Sports Sciences.
